para.inline: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: r asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a principle of broadcasting in Australia that the national and commercial stations exist for the purpose of providing listeners with a choice of programmes and avoiding presentation of one point of view in news, commentaries and sporting events?
Is it a fact that, till recently this attitude has been maintained by the Australian Broadcasting Commission?

Is it a fact that on the 24th November, some commercial stations in Sydney were broadcasting through the courtesy of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, descriptions of the New South Wales Lawn Tennis Championships and also the cricket fixture, New South Wales versus South Australia, being played in Adelaide?
If so, will he take steps to see that this practice is discontinued, and thus -preserve the identity of each section of our broadcasting system ?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows :-

item.para: Yes. The existence of both national and commercial stations ensures a wide variety of programmes for listeners.
The Australian Broadcasting Commission has informed me that there has been no change in its general attitude in this regard.
Yes.

The Commission has informed me that it considers that as many listeners as possible should be given an opportunity of hearing these broadcasts, and on certain occasions for the benefit of listeners, permission is given to some commercial stations to participate in these broadcasts.

talk.start.para: s asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Was an appeal made recently to private enterprise to decentralize important industrial undertakings as a precaution against destruction by air attack?
Is it a fact that the Government has arranged . extensive additions to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories at Royal Park?
Are the serum laboratories located within 2 J miles of the General Post Office, Melbourne ?
Are the laboratories the sole institution of the kind in Australia?
Does the safety, not only of the .people of Australia, but of millions in neighbouring territories, depend largely on the survival of this institution?
Is it proposed that a new area of buildings shall be added to the existing centralized institution ?
Does the centralized situation render the institution vulnerable to air attack?
Is the proposal opposed to public interest and at variance with the Government's advice to private enterprise to decentralize its works?

talk.start.para: - The answers to his questions are as follows : -

item.para: The Commonwealth Government favours the decentralization of important industrial undertakings wherever practicable.
Yes, the work is now in progress.
Within 3i miles of the General Post Office.
Yes.
In some respects the laboratories are essential to the safety of the people referred to.
See answer to 2.
Not necessarily.

No. The nature of the laboratories' activities makes it impossible to effect a satisfactory dispersal of them. It is realized that a -policy of decentralization will involve additional expenditure, but in this instance as well as heavy additional expenditure for buildings and other charges, decentralization would necessitate duplication of specially imported equipment. It would also require the provision of many additional trained workers and qualified medical and technical personnel. It is difficult to obtain sufficient suitable personnel even with the present arrangement.

talk.start.para: s asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice -

item.para: What is the present strength of the (a) Navy (Permanent, Citizen and Reserve

question.para: Forces); (b) Army (Permanent and Citizen Forces) ; and (c) Royal Australian Air Force (Permanent, Citizen and Reserve Forces)?

item.para: Where is each arm of the Services located, and whether in Korea or elsewhere?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the right honorable member's questions are as follows : - 1. (a) Navy (as at the 1st November, 1950) - Permanent Forces, 11,011; Reserve Forces, 5,317. The Reserve Forces include the Royal Australian Navy Reserve (Sea-going), Royal Australian Naval Reserve, Royal Australian Naval Volunteer Reserve, Royal Fleet Reserve and Royal Australian Fleet Reserve. (6) Army (as at the 22nd November, 1950) - Fulltime duty personnel, 17,087; Citizen Military Force personnel, 18,068. (c) Air Force (as at 8th December, 1950) - Permanent Force, 10,911; Citizen and Reserve Forces, 0,792.

item.para: Permanent Naval Forces are located in Australian ships, including two destroyers in Korean waters and in shore establishments, including H.M.A.S. Commonwealth in Japan and H.M.A.S. Tarangau in New Guinea. Reserve Naval Forces are all located in Australia.

answer.para: One battalion of the Permanent Force and a small base detachment are serving in Korea and there is an Army Component serving with the British Commonwealth Occupation Force in Japan. The remainder of the Permanent Force is located in Australia. Personnel of the Citizen Military Forces are located in Australia only.

There is a Royal Australian Air Force Fighter Squadron in Korea which has its supporting and base units in Korea and Japan. A bomber squadron and a transport squadron are operating in Malaya in connexion with the campaign against the guerrillas. The remainder of the Permanent Royal Australian Air Force and the Citizen and the Reserve Air Forces are located in Australia.

talk.start.para: on asked the Prime Minister the following questions, upon notice : -

item.para: Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Office of Education some months ago ceased publishing its discussion posters?
Is it a fact that these posters were regarded by educationalists as excellent teaching aids?

If publication has been discontinued, was it because of cost and, if so, was any approach made to subscribers to ascertain whether they were prepared to pay more for a continuance of what was regarded by them as one of the most valuable activities of the Commonwealth Office of Education ?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Yes.
Yes.

The reason for discontinuing publication of the posters was partly one of cost and partly because of certain administrative difficulties. No approach was made to subscribers to ascertain whether they were prepared to pay more for the posters. It was considered that the falling off of subscribers resulting from a large increase in costs would have more than offset the additional revenue and at the same time would have increased unit costs.

item.para: How many bills were introduced by the Government and how many were passed in the House of Representatives for (a) the period which ended in June, 1950, and (5) for the present period of sittings?

item.para: Is it a fact that in Vaughan House, Melbourne, certain space was rented by his department and left unoccupied for many months?

What explanation is there for leaving so much space unoccupied for so long?
Why was the Reporting Branch of the Attorney-General's Department not directed to occupy the space referred to,before the lapse of so many months?

item.para: Yes.
2,783 square feet for approximately nine months; annual rental £1,263 6s. 8d.
Delay in completing the work necessary to prepare the space for occupation for the special purposes of the Reporting Branch of the Attorney-General's Department.

talk.start.para: s. - On the 19th October, 1950, the honorable member for Grayndler (Mr. Daly) asked the following questions, upon notice -

item.para: How many persons were employed by the Commonwealth at the 31st December, 1949, and 30th September, 1950?
If there has been an increase in the number of employees, in what departments have increases occurred, and by how many?
What departments have been abolished and how many employees were concerned?
Were these employees dismissed or transferred to other departments?
What departments were increased by transfers and by how many?

question.para: I now supply the following answers: -

item.para: The total number of persons employed by public authorities of the Commonwealth was 196,798 in December, 1949, and 201,426 in September, 1950. Theseinclude employees in services such as the post office, railways, air transport, constructional works, scientific research, munition factories, &c., as well as those engaged in administration. These figures are collected by the Commonwealth Statistician and refer in the main to employees on the last pay-roll of the months stated. They cannot be dissected into departmental totals but are periodically dissected into functional groups.

The number of employees engaged under the Public Service Act is recorded by the Public Service Board in departmental totals and comparative figures showing increases and decreases are shown in the attached statement as at the 31st December, 1949, and 30th September, 1950. The statement shows a net increase of 3,471 during this period, but this figure includes an increase of 5,205 in the Post Office which is of course expanding facilities for the public rapidly. There has been an overall decrease of 1,734 in other departments.
In the period in question, two departments were abolished -

question.para: Department of Information on 22nd March, 1950 - 357 employees.
Ministry of Post-war Reconstruction on 12th January, 1950 - 1,547 employees.

One department was created, viz.: - Ministry of National Development on 16th March, 1950. In addition, the title of the Department of Supply and Development was altered to that of Department of Supply and the Departments of Snipping and Fuel and Transport were amalgamated into a single Department of Fuel, Shipping and Transport. The net effect of these changes was to reduce the number of departments by two. 4 and 5. Most employees in the two departments which were abolished were transferred to other departments. The actual staff movements from these two departments were -

subdebate.1.para: It is understood that since the Short-wave Broadcasting Division was transferred to the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the services of 49 employees have been terminated.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister the following questions, upon notice: -

item.para: How many officers were employed by the Department of Information at the time of ite dissolution T
How many such officers were transferred' to other departments; and what were the departments to which they were transferred?
How many such officers are now employed in the departments to which they were transferred ?
What savings were effected in man-power and money from the dissolution of the department to the 30th November last?

talk.start.para: s. - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : - . - 1. At the time of ite dissolution the Department of Information employed 357 staff, com- prising 300 Australian-based staff and 57 locally engaged employees overseas.

item.para: Of the 300 Australian-based staff, 273 were transferred to other departments or Commonwealth agencies. Transfers were to Department of the Interior, 163; to Australian Broadcasting Commission, 94; to vacancies in various departments, 16; total, 273. (Twelve of the 94 transferred to the Australian Broadcasting Commission were later transferred to the Department of External Affairs). Of the remaining 27, eleven resigned and sixteen were retrenched. The 57 locally engaged employees overseas were brought under the control of* the Department of the Interior.

160 Australian-based staff and 37 locally engaged staff overseas are now employed by the Department of the Interior in the News and Information Bureau. Three locally engaged staff in London are . employed by the Prime Minister's Department . and two by the Australian Consulate in New York, following the transfer of libraries from the Department of the Interior to these agencies. The Australian Broadcasting Commission -advises that 48 former Department of Information staff are now employed in the Australian ' Broadcasting Commission. Eleven are employed in the Department of External Affairs, out of the twelve transferred from the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

The savings effected- in man-power from the- dissolution of the department to 30th November, 1950, were: - Australian-based staff, 80; locally engaged staff overseas, 1-6; total, 95. These figures include some staff who have been absorbed into sections which are distinct from the organization of the former Department of Information. A figure for the savings in money resulting from these reductions in employment and the closing down of offices and restrictions in broadcasts is not supplied. This' information could be prepared only with considerable difficulty. However, employment figures show that the pay-roll of staff of the former Department of Information hae been reduced by more than a quarter.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister the following questions, upon notice: -

item.para: Is it a fact that approximately 2,000 women employed in the Postmaster-General's Department and' other federal departments suffered a loss of pay amounting to 13s, 9d. on last pay-day?
Should this sum have been paid to them for cost of living adjustment due for the first full pay in November?
Is it a fact that the stoppage of this amount was due to an instruction issued by the Public -Service Board? If so, did the board collaborate with the Government before issuing this instruction?
Have some of these women been performing* exactly the same kind of -work as men in the Mail Branches of the Postmaster-General's Department at the same rates of pay for the past nine years?
Will his Government take action to restore the pay and conditions enjoyed for years by these women under a Labour government?

talk.start.para: s. - The cost of living adjustment to the basic wage, payable from the first full pay period in November was withheld from certain female employees - in the Postmaster-General's . Department. The employees concerned were some 3,000 females employed in positions which were previously occupied by females and who have been paid male rates, or a percentage of male rates, under decisions of the Women's Employment Board. This action was taken by the Government through the Public Service Board pending certain consultations with the High Council of Public Service Organizations and the Amalgamated Postal Workers' Unions. Agreement was later reached with these bodies that - (1) In the absence of any major change in circumstances, females occupying Fourth Division positions and whose employment commenced or commences prior to 14th December, 1950, will continue to be paid on the basis of the Women's Employment Board Determinations whilst they remain in the respective positions occupied at 14th December, 1950, and (2) females who commence employment in Fourth Division positions on or subsequent to 14th December, 1950, will he paid 75 per cent, of the -basic wage for males plus the full margin for skill where they are equal in efficiency to males and are doing the same work.
